newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian trade unions to strike on Thursday.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian trade unions to strike on Thursday.

text.p: Slovenia's trade unions said on Wednesday they will stage a two-hour general strike on Thursday to press employers not to reduce workers' benefits.

"Employers are wrong if they expect to ensure another 35,000 jobs by cutting social benefits. They act as if they do not need workers," Rajko Lesjak, secretary of the Association of Free Trade Unions, told Reuters.
He said the unions would continue to exert pressure on employers after Thursday's strike.
But Chamber of Economy president Jozko Cuk said that the strike action was illegal because unions had refused to enter negotiations over the dispute.
"We have been pushing for negotiations on the issue since September, 1995," Cuk told a news conference.
Early this month employers said they wanted to amend a collective agreement introduced in 1990 and renewed in 1993.
With effect from April next year they plan to reduce holiday pay, sick pay, strike compensation pay, redundancy pay and daily allowances for workers at financially troubled companies.

Slovenia was hit by a wave of pay strikes over the summer and the government gave in to many demands. Analysts say that unrestrained growth in Slovanian wages could fuel inflation and endanger economic stability.
